questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an animal bite. He was hiking earlier that day when he was bitten by a raccoon. He says the attack was unprovoked and the animal ran away after the encounter. His immunizations are up-to-date. His immunization record shows he received 3 doses of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine as a child and a tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccination at the age of 16. He is in no apparent distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mm Hg. There is a wound on his left lower extremity with actively bleeding puncture sites. The wound is thoroughly irrigated with normal saline and cleansed with antiseptic and a bandage is applied. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tetanus booster, rabies immunoglobulin, and vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Despite being vaccinated for tetanus < 5 years ago with ≥ 3 doses during childhood, this patient requires further management after being bitten by a wild animal known to be a reservoir for the rabies virus.

B) INCORRECT:

A tetanus booster is only indicated as standalone postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in patients with a dirty and/or severe puncture wound if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient. In addition, the rabies vaccine is only given as standalone PEP in those who have previously received the rabies vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

A tetanus booster would be indicated in patients with a dirty and/or severe puncture wound if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case here. Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis, but it is generally administered alongside another prevention measure.

D) INCORRECT:

Rabies vaccination is given as standalone postexposure prophylaxis in patients who have previously received the rabies vaccine. However, this patient has never received the rabies vaccine as it is not part of the routine childhood immunization schedule.

E) INCORRECT:

A tetanus booster would be indicated in cases of a dirty and/or severe puncture wound if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient. Rabies immunoglobulin plus vaccine constitute the rabies postexposure prophylaxis for individuals who have not previously received the vaccine.

F) INCORRECT:

Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis, but it is generally administered alongside another prevention measure. Immunoglobulin alone is not a sufficient prophylaxis.

G) CORRECT:

A bite injury from a wild animal known to be a reservoir for rabies virus (e.g, raccoons) warrants postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) if the animal is not available for testing (as in this case) or if the test comes back positive. In individuals who have not received prior immunization against the rabies virus, PEP should include both the rabies immunoglobulin and vaccine. Apart from raccoons, the most common animal reservoirs of rabies in the US are bats, skunks, and foxes. Worldwide, the most common animal reservoir is dogs.

In addition, patients with either a clean and/or dirty wound should also be evaluated for tetanus PEP. This patient's last tetanus-containing vaccination was < 5 years ago and he has received ≥ 3 doses during his routine childhood vaccination schedule; therefore, tetanus PEP is not indicated in this patient, even in the case of a potentially dirty and/or severe puncture wound.
questions.hint: This patient is at risk of developing rabies and/or tetanus. He has received ≥ 3 doses of tetanus-containing vaccines as part of his routine childhood immunization schedule and his last dose was < 5 years ago, but he is not immunized against the rabies virus.

questions.text: A previously healthy 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of extreme agitation and confusion. He is unable to give a clear history. His mother says he returned from a cave exploring trip 4 weeks ago. Over the past few days, he has had fever and malaise with a sore throat. He has refused to drink any liquids for the last day. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. His pupils are 6 mm and reactive to light. He has a moderate amount of drool. Muscle tone is greatly increased in both the upper and lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is not performed because the patient becomes combative and refuses further assessment. Serum and urine toxicology screens are negative. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are immunosuppressants that are usually administered for a variety of autoimmune conditions (e.g., myasthenia gravis, systemic lupus erythematosus) and cancers, as well as to prevent complications due to scarring after community-acquired bacterial meningitis. However, the clinical presentation of this patient is consistent with encephalitic rabies, which is not treated with corticosteroids, as they cannot halt the neurological damage caused by the rabies virus.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is a treatment option for several disease (e.g., Guillain–Barré syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy). It works by removing antibodies from the plasma of the patient. However, this patient's clinical presentation is consistent with encephalitic rabies, where the rabies virus (and not antibodies) destroy the nerve cells. Therefore, plasmapheresis will not help in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Antifungal therapy is typically administered in patients with histoplasmosis, which is also often associated with recent cave visits. Histoplasmosis frequently manifests with flulike illness, weight loss, erythema nodosum, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and nonproductive cough. Although this patient recently visited a number of caves, his clinical presentation is consistent with encephalitic rabies caused by an infection with the rabies virus, which cannot be treated with an antifungal agent.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy is typically indicated in the case of viral encephalitis, which usually presents with CNS symptoms and personality changes. Although this patient presents with CNS symptoms, which may mimic viral encephalitis, his clinical presentation is consistent with encephalitic rabies caused by the rabies virus. However, there is no available antiviral therapy that stops the replication of the rabies virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy would be administered if the patient's clinical presentation were due to an infectious cause treatable with antibiotics (e.g., bacterial, protozoal). However, this patient presents with symptoms associated with encephalitic rabies due to an infection with rabies virus, so antibiotics cannot help in this case.

F) CORRECT:

Preexposure prophylaxis with an inactivated vaccine is recommended for individuals with frequent occupational or recreational contact with potentially rabid animals (e.g., cave explorers, such as this patient, and veterinarians, animal handlers, or rabies laboratory workers). In addition, preexposure prophylaxis is indicated for travelers to regions in which rabies is widespread, especially if postexposure prophylaxis may not be readily available (see “Overview of travel immunizations” table). Apart from bats, the most common animal reservoirs of rabies in the US are raccoons, skunks, and foxes. Encephalitic rabies usually leads to coma and death within days to weeks of the development of neurological symptoms. At the patient's stage of the disease, only palliative treatment is available.

Immunoglobulin and vaccination administration are recommended as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for individuals exposed to rabies. The anti-rabies virus immunoglobulin provides immediate protection by binding to the rabies virus and thereby neutralizing it. However, protection is only temporary, since the antibodies degrade and the titers decrease over time. The simultaneous administration of the rabies vaccine stimulates the body's immune system, which reacts by producing antibodies. Treatment with PEP in suspected cases of a rabid animal bite should take place immediately, as the disease is fatal once it is symptomatic.
questions.hint: The patient has had flu-like illness followed by agitation, confusion, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, and increased muscle tone 4 weeks following his recent cave visit. This corresponds to the incubation period for rabies (4–12 weeks average) and highly suggests encephalitic rabies due to a bat bite.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after being bitten by his neighbor's dog. He was chasing the dog with a stick when it attacked him. He has fed the dog on multiple occasions and it has never bitten him before. His father saw the dog 2 hours after the incident and its behavior seemed normal. There is no personal or family history of serious illness in the family. The last vaccination the boy received was against varicella 2 years ago; he has never been immunized against rabies. He is not in acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 2-cm (0.8 in) puncture wound on his left calf; there is minimal erythema around the wound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. The wound is irrigated and washed with saline and chlorhexidine solution. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Euthanize the dog and test for rabies
Administer rabies vaccine and immune globulin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Following a provoked bite injury by a domestic carnivore that does not display symptoms of rabies, a 10-day observation period of the animal is the next best step for assessing the risk of rabies. Because rabies has a long incubation period (usually 1–3 months) and animals that can transmit rabies develop symptoms within 5–10 days, postponing PEP to observe the animal is safe. If the dog maintains normal behavior for the duration of the observation, no PEP is necessary. If the dog develops symptoms of rabies, the dog is tested and PEP is initiated in the patient. If the tests are negative, PEP is discontinued.

An important exception is a bite wound to the head or neck (closer to central nervous tissue), as there are reports of cases in which rabies infection occurred within 4 days of exposure. Therefore, PEP should be initiated immediately in patients with bite wounds to the head or neck.

B) INCORRECT:

Euthanizing and testing the dog for rabies would only be indicated if the dog exhibits signs of rabies (e.g., abnormal behavior). The National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians (NASPHV) and the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also recommend that any stray or unwanted dog that bites a person, may be euthanized immediately by an animal health professional and the head should be submitted for rabies testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of both rabies vaccine and immune globulin is the preferred method of PEP in previously unvaccinated individuals. However, in this unvaccinated patient who has been bitten by a pet that is available for testing, PEP is not yet indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Rabies immune globulin is part of PEP in unvaccinated individuals. However, PEP is not yet indicated for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Administration of rabies vaccine is the preferred method of postexposure prophylaxis in patients who had been previously vaccinated. However, PEP is not yet indicated for this patient. Additionally, this patient has not been vaccinated in the past.
questions.hint: After a potential rabies exposure, the type of animal and the context of the bite injury should be taken into consideration when evaluating the need for postexposure prophylaxis (PEP).

questions.text: An investigator is developing a drug that selectively inhibits the retrograde axonal transport of rabies virus towards the central nervous system. To achieve this effect, this drug must target which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tubulin is a globular protein that polymerizes into filaments of heterodimers (pairs of α- and β-tubulin) to form microtubules. As a structural component of microtubules, tubulin is involved in spreading the rabies virus to the CNS via retrograde transport. However, drugs that inhibit polymerization into microtubules by binding tubulin (e.g., colchicine, vincristine, and vinblastine) would not only inhibit retrograde transport, but also anterograde transport and impair the structural stability of the neuron.
Image Description:

In microtubule polymerization, GTP-tubulin dimers (each made up of an α-tubulin and a β-tubulin) accumulate at the plus end. The GTP of β-tubulin spontaneously hydrolyzes shortly afterwards, leading to loss of microtubule stability. Microtubules do not depolymerize if GTP-tubulin dimers are present at the plus end.

The minus end is usually located in the centrosome of the cell, the microtubule organizing center, where it is stabilized by γ-tubulin and capping proteins. In principle, tubulin dimers could also accumulate at the minus end; however, attachment would be very slow (e.g., when a microtubule breaks).

B) INCORRECT:

Kinesin is an ATP-dependent motor protein responsible for the anterograde migration and movement of cellular organelles and proteins along microtubules (especially important in axons). Disrupting the integrity of kinesin would impair the transport of proteins from the cell body (soma) of neurons to the axon tip. Rabies virus does not use the kinesin motor system to spread to the CNS.

C) CORRECT:

Dynein is an ATP-dependent motor protein responsible for the retrograde migration and movement of cellular organelles and proteins along microtubules in axons. After rabies exposure, the rabies virus binds to acetylcholine receptors and enters the motor and sensory nerves of the peripheral nervous system, spreading in a retrograde direction to the CNS. To inhibit the migration of the virus and subsequent brain infection, the new drug must therefore target dynein motors.

D) INCORRECT:

Nidogen (also known as entactin) is a ubiquitous glycoprotein that constitutes an intrinsic component of the basement membrane. It is found in high concentrations near neuromuscular junction synapses and has been identified as binding site of tetanus toxin to neurons, which is required for retrograde transport of tetanus toxin towards the axonal soma. However, nidogen does not relate to the transport of rabies virus within axons.

E) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (not acetylcholine itself) have been implicated as the binding site of the rabies virus to axons. A drug targeting these receptors could inhibit the entry of rabies virus into neurons, but it would not selectively impair the retrograde axonal transport towards the CNS.
questions.hint: Rabies virus travels from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system (CNS) with the aid of motor proteins that facilitate the movement of cargo proteins across axons.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-week history of progressive confusion, myalgia, and nausea. His wife says that he first reported headaches and fatigue 10 days ago, and since then “he has not been himself”. He has refused to drink any liquids for the last day. Two months ago, he helped his neighbor remove a raccoon's den from her backyard. He appears agitated. His temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C). Examination shows excessive drooling. Muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes are increased bilaterally. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

NRTIs and NNRTIs are RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibitors and are used in antiretroviral HIV therapy. An acute HIV infection can manifest with fever, headache, and fatigue, as seen in this patient. However, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, and increased muscle tone and reflexes are not associated with HIV. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibitors are not effective against rabies virus.

B) CORRECT:

Administration of a chemically-inactivated virus (i.e., killed vaccine) along with rabies immunoglobulin is recommended as postexposure prophylaxis for patients exposed to suspected rabies. The immunoglobulin provides immediate protection by binding to the rabies virus and neutralizing it (i.e., passive immunity). However, protection is only temporary, since antibodies degrade over time. Simultaneous administration of the rabies vaccine stimulates the body's immune system, which reacts by producing antibodies (i.e., active immunity). Preventive active immunization with rabies vaccine is indicated for people with frequent occupational contact with potentially rabid animals and travelers to regions in which rabies is widespread.

Treatment with postexposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of a rabid animal bite should take place immediately, as the disease is fatal once it has become symptomatic. At this patient's stage of the disease, only palliative treatment is available.

C) INCORRECT:

Immunization with live attenuated vaccine usually provides lifelong protection against a virus or bacterium (e.g., MMR vaccine). However, there is no live vaccine available against rabies virus.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of immunoglobulins is an integral part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis; immunoglobulins provide immediate protection by binding to the rabies virus and thereby neutralizing it. However, rabies is a virus that belongs to the Rhabdoviridae. Therefore, an immunoglobulin against a bacterial protein would not be effective.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are NF-κB inhibitors that are usually administered for a variety of autoimmune conditions, as well as to prevent complications due to scarring after community-acquired bacterial meningitis. However, the clinical presentation of this patient is consistent with encephalitic rabies, which is not treated with corticosteroids, as they cannot halt the neurological damage caused by the rabies virus.

F) INCORRECT:

Ribavirin, an inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase inhibitor, is used for the treatment of hepatitis C and RSV infection. None of these conditions is consistent with this patient's clinical presentation, which is suggestive of encephalitic rabies. There is no available antiviral therapy that stops the replication of rabies virus.
questions.hint: The patient has had flulike illness followed by agitation, confusion, hydrophobia, hypersalivation, and increased muscle tone and reflexes 2 months following exposure to raccoons. These symptoms are highly suggestive of rabies infection due to a bite by a raccoon, which are a major animal reservoir of rabies.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because they are concerned he was bitten by a bat. Thirty minutes ago, they found him crying in his bed, where he was taking a nap, while a bat was flying around the room. The bat left the room when the father opened a window. The patient has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no visible bite marks. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An RT-PCR for rabies RNA can be used for the diagnosis of rabies and usually requires multiple samples from saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, serum, and skin. However, rabies RNA is only detectable when the disease becomes symptomatic, at which point the outcome is almost always fatal. In a patient in whom exposure is suspected or cannot be ruled out, a different intervention is required.

B) INCORRECT:

Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) with rabies immunoglobulin (Ig) is indicated in all nonimmunized patients who have been potentially exposed to rabies. However, the administration of rabies Ig alone only provides temporary protection and does not induce an adequate immune response in these patients. A different PEP regimen should be considered in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is indicated in all nonimmunized individuals after potential exposure to rabies because of the fatal progression of the disease once it becomes symptomatic. Animal bites may not be readily apparent on physical examination and some patients, such as children, may not be able to reliably report direct contact with the animal. Therefore, any possibility of contact (in this case, a bat in the patient's bedroom) warrants immediate rabies PEP when the animal is not available for testing. PEP consists of one dose of rabies immunoglobulin on the day of exposure and 4 doses of inactivated rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 after exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

A bite from a vaccinated domestic carnivore or domestic herbivore does not usually require any further action. However, any suspected direct contact with a known wild reservoir of rabies, such as bats, requires immediate intervention because of the extremely high fatality rate and limited treatment options for this disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Postexposure prophylaxis with rabies vaccine should be considered in all previously vaccinated patients who have potentially been exposed to rabies. As the rabies vaccine is not part of the regular immunization schedule in the US, it is unlikely that this patient has already received it. Therefore, a different intervention is required.
questions.hint: Bats, raccoons, skunks, and foxes are the most common animal reservoir of rabies in the US.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is concerned about a dog bite he received 6 days ago while he was jogging during a visit to Mexico. He states that he tried to shoo the dog away, but it ran up to him and bit his leg. He has never previously received rabies vaccination. He has no other medical conditions.
Physical examination reveals a superficial, clean wound on his right calf that is healing well.
Which one of the following steps is most appropriate for managing this patient’s dog bite?

choices.text: Infiltrate the wound with rabies immunoglobulin
No rabies prophylaxis is necessary; treat the wound with amoxicillin-clavulanate
Infiltrate the right calf with rabies immunoglobulin; initiate postexposure rabies vaccination
No rabies prophylaxis or antibiotic treatment is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immunocompetent patients who have not been previously vaccinated should receive four doses of vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 — in addition to a single dose of rabies immunoglobulin on day 0.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with a high-risk exposure to rabies, such as a dog bite that occurred in Mexico and punctured the skin, should receive postexposure prophylaxis. If the wound is superficial and healing well, it does not require treatment with antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Immunocompetent patients who have not been previously vaccinated should receive four doses of vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 — in addition to a single dose of rabies immunoglobulin on day 0.

D) CORRECT:

Rabies infection from domestic dogs in the United States is exceedingly rare and is more likely to occur from exposure to bats, skunks, or raccoons. However, globally (including in Mexico), dogs are the major reservoirs of the rabies virus. Exposure to rabies, a Lyssavirus, occurs when the skin is penetrated by teeth or when a person has direct transdermal or mucosal contact with infectious material, such as brain tissue or saliva from an infected animal.

Patients with a high-risk exposure to rabies, such as a dog bite that occurred in Mexico and punctured the skin, should receive postexposure prophylaxis consisting of three primary elements:

1 Wound care.

2 Administration of rabies immunoglobulin. When the wound is visible, as much of the dose as is feasible should be infiltrated directly in and around the wound.

3 Administration of rabies vaccine.

Immunocompetent patients who have not been previously vaccinated should receive four doses of vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 — in addition to a single dose of rabies immunoglobulin on day 0. People who have previously received a vaccine series do not require immunoglobulin and should receive two doses of the vaccine on days 0 and 3.

If the wound is superficial and healing well, it does not require treatment with antibiotics.

Key learning point: A person who is bitten by an animal that is at high risk for rabies should be managed with postexposure vaccination and administration of immunoglobulin.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with a high-risk exposure to rabies, such as a dog bite that occurred in Mexico and punctured the skin, should receive postexposure prophylaxis. If the wound is superficial and healing well, it does not require treatment with antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after he was bitten on the arms and hands by a stray dog. He had been playing by himself when he was bitten, and the dog could not be found after the incident. He is completely up to date on his vaccinations.
He is crying at presentation, but his vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals several jagged lacerations on his arms and hands. The wound is copiously irrigated, antibiotics are initiated, and animal control is contacted.
Which one of the following additional steps, if any, is indicated before discharge from the emergency department?

choices.text: Rabies immunoglobulin and initiation of rabies vaccine series
Initiation of rabies vaccine series only
Tetanus immunoglobulin and diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient was bitten by a stray dog that cannot be located. Animal control should be contacted immediately, and the wounds should be thoroughly irrigated with copious amounts of sterile water or saline solution, using pressure irrigation. Because the patient has wounds on his hands (a location considered to be at high risk for infection), antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated. The recommended antimicrobial regimen for adequate coverage of the pathogens most commonly involved in dog bites is amoxicillin-clavulanate for 3 to 5 days. In addition, the possibility of both rabies and tetanus transmission should be considered.

Rabies transmission must always be considered when the bite is from a wild animal (especially a bat or carnivore) or from a domestic animal that has uncertain immunization status and is unable to be captured for quarantine. Both the type of animal and the geographic location of potential rabies exposure are important when considering rabies prophylaxis. For example, in developing countries, dogs account for at least 90% of rabies cases in humans. However, in the United States, the probability of rabies transmission from dogs to humans has declined dramatically in recent years. Thus, current recommendations in the United States are to quarantine the dog for 10 days and to start rabies postexposure prophylaxis only if symptoms develop. If the dog is rabid or suspected of being rabid, such as in the setting of an unprovoked attack, postexposure prophylaxis should be started promptly. Public health officials should be contacted for risk assessment and advice when there is any uncertainty about the risk for rabies.

When postexposure prophylaxis is indicated in an immunocompetent patient, it should begin as soon as possible after exposure and include both passive and active prophylaxis with human rabies immunoglobulin and the initiation of a four-dose rabies vaccine series. All suspected human cases of rabies should be reported promptly to public health authorities. Given that the stray dog in this scenario cannot be located for observation, postexposure prophylaxis for rabies should be initiated promptly, with human rabies immunoglobulin and rabies vaccine. Neither treatment alone is sufficient for rabies protection in this case.

Any open wound is a potential site of tetanus transmission, but wounds contaminated with dirt, feces, soil, or saliva (including animal bite wounds) are at increased risk; this patient should therefore be considered for tetanus prophylaxis.

• Patients who have received fewer than three doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines (or have an unknown history of such vaccination) should receive an additional tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine and tetanus immunoglobulin.
• Patients who have received at least three doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines do not require tetanus immunoglobulin and would only need another dose of vaccine if more than 5 years had passed since the last dose.

Given that this patient is completely up to date on his vaccinations, he should have received at least three doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines by 6 months of age. He therefore does not need any additional tetanus vaccine or treatment as part of his bite-wound management.

Key learning point: The most appropriate rabies postexposure prophylaxis for a child who has been bitten by a stray dog is rabies immunoglobulin and initiation of the rabies vaccine series.

B) INCORRECT:

When postexposure prophylaxis is indicated in an immunocompetent patient, it should begin as soon as possible after exposure and include both passive and active prophylaxis with human rabies immunoglobulin and the initiation of a four-dose rabies vaccine series. Neither treatment alone is sufficient for rabies protection in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

When postexposure prophylaxis is indicated in an immunocompetent patient, it should begin as soon as possible after exposure and include both passive and active prophylaxis with human rabies immunoglobulin and the initiation of a four-dose rabies vaccine series. Neither treatment alone is sufficient for rabies protection in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Any open wound is a potential site of tetanus transmission, but wounds contaminated with dirt, feces, soil, or saliva (including animal bite wounds) are at increased risk; this patient should therefore be considered for tetanus prophylaxis. Patients who have received fewer than three doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines (or have an unknown history of such vaccination) should receive an additional tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine and tetanus immunoglobulin. Patients who have received at least three doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines do not require tetanus immunoglobulin and would only need another dose of vaccine if more than 5 years had passed since the last dose. Given that this patient is completely up to date on his vaccinations, he should have received at least three doses of tetanus toxoid-containing vaccines by 6 months of age. He therefore does not need any additional tetanus vaccine or treatment as part of his bite-wound management.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient was bitten by a stray dog that cannot be located. Animal control should be contacted immediately, and the wounds should be thoroughly irrigated with copious amounts of sterile water or saline solution, using pressure irrigation. Because the patient has wounds on his hands (a location considered to be at high risk for infection), antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated. The recommended antimicrobial regimen for adequate coverage of the pathogens most commonly involved in dog bites is amoxicillin-clavulanate for 3 to 5 days. In addition, the possibility of both rabies and tetanus transmission should be considered. Given that the stray dog in this scenario cannot be located for observation, postexposure prophylaxis for rabies should be initiated promptly, with human rabies immunoglobulin and rabies vaccine. Neither treatment alone is sufficient for rabies protection in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an animal bite. He was hiking earlier that day when he was bitten by a raccoon. He says the attack was unprovoked and the animal ran away after the encounter. His immunizations are up-to-date. His immunization record shows he received 3 doses of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine as a child and a tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccination at the age of 16. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is a wound on his left lower extremity with actively bleeding puncture sites. The wound is thoroughly irrigated with normal saline and cleansed with antiseptic and a bandage is applied. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tetanus booster, rabies immunoglobulin, and vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A tetanus booster is only indicated as standalone postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in patients with a dirty and/or severe puncture wound if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient. In addition, the rabies vaccine is only given as standalone PEP in those who have previously received the rabies vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Rabies vaccination is given as standalone postexposure prophylaxis in patients who have previously received the rabies vaccine. However, this patient has never received the rabies vaccine as it is not part of the routine childhood immunization schedule.

C) INCORRECT:

A tetanus booster would be indicated in cases of a dirty and/or severe puncture wound if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient. Rabies immunoglobulin plus vaccine constitute the rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for individuals who have not previously received the vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis, but it is generally administered alongside another prevention measure. Immunoglobulin alone is not a sufficient prophylaxis.

E) CORRECT:

A bite injury from a wild animal known to be a reservoir for rabies virus (e.g, raccoons) warrants postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) if the animal is not available for testing (as in this case) or if the test comes back positive. In individuals who have not received prior immunization against the rabies virus, PEP should include both the rabies immunoglobulin and vaccine. Apart from raccoons, the most common animal reservoirs of rabies in the US are bats, skunks, and foxes. Worldwide, the most common animal reservoir is dogs.

In addition, patients with either a clean and/or dirty wound should also be evaluated for tetanus PEP. This patient's last tetanus-containing vaccination was < 5 years ago and he has received ≥ 3 doses during his routine childhood vaccination schedule; therefore, tetanus PEP is not indicated in this patient, even in the case of a potentially dirty and/or severe puncture wound.
questions.hint: This patient is at risk of developing rabies and/or tetanus. He has received ≥ 3 doses of tetanus-containing vaccines as part of his routine childhood immunization schedule and his last dose was < 5 years ago, but he is not immunized against the rabies virus.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-year-old boy brought to the emergency department by his parents. They found him crying in his bed after a nap, while a bat was flying around the room. The bat flew out when the father opened a window. The child has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has not had any animal bites in the past. His immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals no visible bite marks. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

As the rabies vaccine is not part of the regular immunization schedule in Canada, it is unlikely that this patient has already received it. For individuals who have never received a rabies vaccine, PEP against rabies should include an additional intervention besides rabies vaccination.

B) INCORRECT:

An RT-PCR for rabies RNA can be used for the diagnosis of rabies and usually requires multiple samples from saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, serum, and skin. However, rabies RNA is only detectable when the disease becomes symptomatic, at which point the outcome is almost always fatal. In a patient in whom exposure is suspected or cannot be ruled out, a different intervention is required.

C) CORRECT:

Encounters involving children, cognitively impaired persons, or sleeping individuals demand particular caution; if a bat is found in a child’s room and the child awakens distressed, direct contact should be presumed. Once symptoms appear, rabies is almost always fatal. The Public Health Agency of Canada recommends immediate PEP (regardless of the individual's prior rabies vaccination status) following a high‑risk exposure in which the animal cannot be promptly captured and tested. For individuals who have never received a rabies vaccine, the regimen includes a single dose of human rabies immunoglobulin (RabIg) infiltrated around any wound site (when evident), with the remainder administered intramuscularly, followed by a series of 4–5 rabies vaccine doses given on days 0, 3, 7, and 14 (and optionally on day 28). Patients who have been vaccinated previously still require two booster doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3, but do not need RabIg. PEP can be postponed for up to 48 hours only if the animal is captured and its brain tissue is tested. A negative result allows cessation of any initiated vaccination series.

Key learning point: Postexposure prophylaxis is required after any suspected direct contact with a bat, with previously unvaccinated patients receiving both the rabies immunoglobulin and the vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

A bite from a vaccinated domestic carnivore does not usually require any further action. However, any suspected direct contact with a known wild reservoir of rabies, such as bats, requires immediate intervention because of the extremely high fatality rate and limited treatment options for this disease.

E) INCORRECT:

PEP with rabies immunoglobulin (RabIg) is indicated in all nonimmunized patients who have been potentially exposed to rabies. However, the administration of rabies Ig alone only provides temporary protection and does not induce an adequate immune response in these patients. A different PEP regimen should be considered in this case.
questions.hint: In Canada, the primary rabies reservoirs are wild carnivores (e.g., raccoons, skunks, foxes) and bats. Post‑exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is indicated after any bite by a suspected reservoir animal or any bat exposure. Although transmission via non‑bite salivary contamination of mucous membranes or broken skin is extremely rare, bat bites often go unnoticed and leave no visible marks. No region in Canada is considered free from rabies in bats, and even brief contact (e.g., bat landing on clothing) warrants PEP.

questions.text: A 38-year-old accountant presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of fever, malaise, and anxiety. Seven weeks ago, he was bitten by a raccoon while attempting to remove it from his garage. He immediately cleaned the wound with soap and water but did not seek medical attention. He now reports increasing agitation and difficulty swallowing, with episodes of throat spasms when trying to drink. What should have been done immediately after the initial exposure?

choices.text: Rabies immune globulin and rabies vaccine series
Observation of the animal for 10 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rabies immune globulin provides only passive immunization through preformed antibodies, offering temporary protection that wanes over time. For unvaccinated patients exposed to high-risk animals like raccoons, passive immunization alone is insufficient. Active immunization with the rabies vaccine series is essential to stimulate the patient's immune system to produce its own antibodies for sustained protection. The combination of both passive and active immunization is required because rabies immune globulin provides immediate but temporary protection while the immune system develops its own response to the vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Unvaccinated patients require both passive immunization with rabies immune globulin and active immunization with the vaccine series. Vaccine alone is insufficient for a high-risk animal exposure in a patient without prior rabies vaccination.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Raccoons are high-risk animals for rabies transmission. Unvaccinated patients require both passive immunization with rabies immune globulin (infiltrated into the wound) and active immunization with the rabies vaccine series administered on days 0, 3, 7, and 14. This patient's current symptoms suggest symptomatic rabies, which could have been prevented with proper postexposure prophylaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

Animal observation for 10 days is only appropriate for domestic animals such as dogs, cats, and ferrets. Wild animals such as raccoons are considered high-risk for rabies, and if the animal cannot be tested, postexposure prophylaxis is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

While tetanus vaccination and wound care are important components of bite wound management, they do not provide protection against rabies. High-risk animal exposures require specific rabies postexposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old immunocompromised patient on long-term prednisone presents after finding a bat in her bedroom upon waking. She reports no memory of contact, and examination shows no visible wounds or scratches. She has no prior rabies vaccination history. The local health department confirms the bat escaped and cannot be captured for testing. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: No prophylaxis needed since there is no evidence of a bite
Observe for 10 days and initiate prophylaxis only if symptoms develop
Administer rabies immune globulin and vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bat exposures with suspected contact require immediate prophylaxis even if there is no visible bite or the animal is not available for testing.

B) INCORRECT:

This approach is inappropriate because rabies postexposure prophylaxis must be initiated immediately after the potential exposure. Once clinical symptoms develop, rabies is almost universally fatal regardless of treatment. Additionally, the incubation period for rabies is usually 4–12 weeks, so the absence of symptoms at 10 days does not exclude an infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Vaccine alone is insufficient since unvaccinated patients require both passive and active immunization. Additionally, this patient requires rabies immune globulin for immediate protection given the high-risk exposure.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Any suspected bat contact requires immediate rabies post-exposure prophylaxis regardless of visible bite evidence. Unvaccinated patients require rabies immunoglobulin plus vaccination on the first visit and repeat vaccination on days 3, 7, and 14. Because this patient is immunocompromised, she will require an additional vaccine dose on day 28.

E) INCORRECT:

Rabies immune globulin provides only passive immunization through preformed antibodies, offering temporary protection that declines over time. For unvaccinated patients exposed to high-risk animals such as bats, passive immunization alone is insufficient. Active immunization with the rabies vaccine series is essential to stimulate the patient's immune system to produce its own antibodies for sustained protection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old veterinarian presents to the emergency department after being bitten by a stray cat during a rescue operation 6 hours ago. She has superficial lacerations on her forearm, which she irrigated with saline. She completed a 3-dose rabies pre-exposure prophylaxis series 18 months ago but never had antibody titers checked. The cat appeared healthy but escaped and is unavailable for observation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No rabies postexposure prophylaxis is necessary since the patient has been vaccinated
Rabies vaccine only on days 0 and 3
Check rabies antibody titers and hold postexposure prophylaxis pending results
Rabies immune globulin infiltrated into the wound plus rabies vaccine on days 0, 3, 7, and 14

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Even previously vaccinated patients require postexposure prophylaxis if the animal is not available for observation. Without postexposure prophylaxis, vaccinated patients will not receive the necessary immune boost required for protection against this universally fatal infection.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Patients who have previously received rabies pre-exposure prophylaxis are considered vaccinated regardless of antibody titers. If the animal bite is from a domestic animal that cannot be observed, vaccinated patients require only the 2-dose vaccine series on days 0 and 3, without rabies immune globulin.

C) INCORRECT:

The 4-dose rabies vaccine schedule is indicated for unvaccinated patients requiring postexposure prophylaxis. Previously vaccinated patients have existing immune memory and require only a 2-dose booster schedule, administered on days 0 and 3.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibody titers are not routinely checked after pre-exposure prophylaxis, and postexposure prophylaxis should not be delayed pending titer results. Previous completion of the pre-exposure series is sufficient to classify the patient as vaccinated.

E) INCORRECT:

This regimen is appropriate for unvaccinated patients who require both passive and active immunization. Since this patient previously received rabies pre-exposure prophylaxis, she is considered vaccinated and does not require rabies immune globulin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a suspected bat bite. He awoke in his rural cabin to find a bat flying in his room. He is unsure if he was bitten but notes two small puncture marks on his right forearm that were not present before he went to sleep. He was able to trap the bat, but it escaped before it could be captured for testing. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has never received a rabies vaccination. His vital signs are normal. Examination shows two superficial puncture wounds on the dorsal forearm without signs of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate postexposure prophylactic regimen for this patient?

choices.text: Human rabies immune globulin infiltrated at the wound site only
Human rabies immune globulin infiltrated at the wound site and rabies vaccine intramuscularly
Observation for 10 days and initiation of treatment only if the animal is found and confirmed rabid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While human rabies immune globulin provides immediate passive immunity, its protection is temporary and wanes over a few weeks. It does not stimulate the body's own long-term immune response. Therefore, active immunization is essential to ensure durable, long-lasting protection against the virus.

B) CORRECT:

For an unimmunized individual with a potential rabies exposure, postexposure prophylaxis requires both passive and active immunization. Human rabies immune globulin provides immediate passive immunity by delivering preformed antibodies to neutralize the virus at the wound site. It should be infiltrated into and around the wounds if anatomically feasible. Concurrently, the rabies vaccine is administered to stimulate the patient's own active immunity. The standard vaccine schedule for an immunocompetent, unimmunized person is four doses given on days 0, 3, 7, and 14. This dual approach is critical because the vaccine-induced antibody response takes time to develop.

C) INCORRECT:

Administering the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 is the standard postexposure prophylaxis for individuals who have been previously vaccinated against rabies. Because this patient has never been vaccinated, he does not have preexisting antibodies and requires immediate passive protection.

D) INCORRECT:

A 10-day observation period is appropriate only for healthy-appearing domestic dogs, cats, or ferrets that can be securely confined. This protocol is not used for wild animals like bats, especially one that has escaped and cannot be tested. Because of the high mortality of rabies, prophylaxis should be initiated immediately in this high-risk exposure situation.
questions.hint: Any suspicion of a bat bite (e.g., waking up with a bat in the room) warrants the administration of rabies postexposure prophylaxis, even if there is no evidence of a bite.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the urgent care clinic for evaluation. He reports that he woke up this morning and found a bat flying in his bedroom. He was able to trap the bat and release it outside. He denies any known bites or scratches and feels well. He is unsure how long the bat was in the room while he was asleep. He has no significant past medical history and has never been vaccinated against rabies. His vital signs are normal. A thorough skin examination shows no visible puncture wounds, scratches, or breaks in the skin. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Administer rabies immune globulin and rabies vaccine
Reassure the patient that no intervention is needed
Observe for 10 days for symptom development

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient requires rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Since the patient has never been vaccinated, PEP consists of both passive and active immunization. Rabies immune globulin (RIG) provides immediate passive immunity with preformed antibodies. The rabies vaccine series stimulates the patient's own immune system to produce long-lasting active immunity. RIG should be infiltrated around any wound site if possible, with the remainder given intramuscularly, while the vaccine is administered at a separate site. This dual approach is critical because rabies is nearly universally fatal once clinical symptoms appear.

B) INCORRECT:

Although there is no visible bite or scratch, the potential for an unrecognized exposure is high because the patient was asleep in the same room as a bat. Public health guidelines explicitly state that this scenario warrants post-exposure prophylaxis due to the high mortality of rabies and the often-unnoticeable nature of bat bites. Reassurance would be inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Administering the rabies vaccine alone is the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis for individuals who have been previously vaccinated against rabies. However, this patient is unvaccinated and therefore lacks pre-existing antibodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Rabies immune globulin provides immediate but temporary passive immunity. While it is a crucial component of post-exposure prophylaxis for an unvaccinated individual, it does not induce a long-term active immune response.

E) INCORRECT:

A 10-day observation period is recommended for healthy domestic dogs, cats, or ferrets that have bitten a human, but it is not applicable to wild animals like bats. Furthermore, waiting for symptoms to develop in a human is never appropriate, as rabies is fatal once symptoms begin.
questions.hint: Finding a bat in a room with a sleeping person is a high-risk exposure for rabies, as bat bites can be small, superficial, and go undetected.
